# Real Productivity

- The **only** way to increase income and standards of living (i.e. GDP per capita) is to increase .shout[real productivity], the amount of output produced per unit of input (i.e. per work-hour)

- Recall the idea of a .shout[production function]:
$$Y=f(L,K)$$

- where $Y$ is output, $L$ is labor, and $K$ is capital (both inputs)

---

# An Aggregate Production Function

.pull-left[
- Consider an **aggregate production function** for a country's entire economy:<sup>.red[1]</sup>

$$Y=f(A,eL,K)$$
- where the factors of production (inputs) are:
    - $A$: technology
    - $e$: education ("human capital")
    - $L$: labor (population)
    - $K$: physical capital 

]

.pull-right[
.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/f5echyv5gt9iypy/productivity1.png?raw=1)
]
]

.footnote[<sup>.red[1]</sup> This is an extremely simplified version of the famous economic model of growth, the Solow model or neoclassical growth model, we'll see soon.]

---

# An Aggregate Production Function II 

.pull-left[

$$Y=f(A, eL, K)$$

- Increases in $L$: population growth
- Increase in $K$: more physical capital
- Increase in $e$: more education
- Increase in $A$: more technology 

]

.pull-right[
.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/f5echyv5gt9iypy/productivity1.png?raw=1)
]
]

---

# Output Per Worker


- A common way to measure .shout[real (labor) productivity] is output per worker
    - Simply divide the production function through by $L$

$$\frac{Y}{L}=f(\frac{A}{L}, e, \frac{K}{L})$$

- $\frac{Y}{L}$: output per worker (labor productivity) 
- Comes from having higher levels of 
    - $\frac{K}{L}$: capital per worker
    - $\frac{A}{L}$: technology per worker
    - $e$: human capital/education

# What Causes Productivity (Differences)?

.pull-left[

- Why isn't the whole world equally productive?
- Different countries have different resources (factors of production)
    - Land, labor, capital, education, technology, etc. 
- Why not take machines and technology from wealthy countries and transfer them to poor countries?
